title: RL31516
content: In the 108th Congress, the Federal Workforce Flexibility Act of 2003 (S. 129) passed the Senate with an amendment by unanimous consent on April 8, 2004. Senator George Voinovich introduced the bill on January 9, 2003, and it was reported with an amendment in the House of Representatives on May 18, 2004. The subcommittee agreed to amendments offered by Representatives Jo Ann Davis and Danny Davis. The bill was ordered to be reported to the House of Representatives after agreeing to the amendments. Another bill related to federal workforce management was introduced in the House in 2003. Representative Jo Ann Davis introduced the Federal Workforce Flexibility Act of 2003. The Senate and House committees held a joint hearing on the federal government's human capital challenge, including discussion of H.R. 1601. Both S. 129 and H.R. 1601 incorporate provisions from S. 2651, the Federal Workforce Improvement Act of 2002. Several provisions from S. 2651 were enacted in P.L. 107-296, including those on agency Chief Human Capital Officers, alternative ranking and selection procedures, voluntary separation incentive payments, and modifications to the National Security Education Program. The Homeland Security Act of 2002, signed by President George Bush, made modifications to the National Security Education Program. S. 129, as passed by the Senate, would amend provisions on critical pay, retirement system computation, agency training, and bonuses. It would also add new sections on recruitment, relocation, and retention bonuses to Title 5 United States Code. S. 129, as passed by the Senate, includes amendments to pay administration and provisions on retirement service credit and compensatory time off for travel. The bill also enhances authority for recruitment, relocation, and retention bonuses. The Senate-passed bill, S. 129, included provisions on Senior Executive Service authority for the White House Office of Administration. Other provisions related to Thrift Savings Plan contributions, annuity commencement dates, and retirement for air traffic controllers were initially included but later removed during the full committee markup. Senator Voinovich introduced the Federal Human Capital Act of 2001 and the Federal Employee Management Reform Act of 2001, while Senator Fred Thompson introduced the Managerial Act. Senator Fred Thompson introduced the Managerial Flexibility Act of 2001, while Representative Constance Morellaintroduced the Good People, Good Government Act. President George W. Bush's Administration submitted The Managerial Flexibility Act of 2001 to Congress, aiming to eliminate legal barriers to effective management. The proposal included provisions for personnel management flexibilities like voluntary separation incentive payments and recruitment bonuses. The Subcommittee on International Security, Proliferation, and Federal Services conducted hearings on civil service bills, resulting in the merging of provisions from S. 1603 and S. 1639 into S. 2651. Some provisions from S. 2651 were enacted in P.L. 107-296, while no further action was taken on other bills from the 107th Congress. This report compares provisions in S. 129 with current law under Title 5 United. The report presents information on retirement provisions under 5 U.S.C. Chapters 83 and 84, as well as Senior Executive Service Authority for the White House Office of Administration under 3 U.S.C. Chapter 2. Prepared by Patrick Purcell and [author name scrubbed] from CRS.
